awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Geoheritage and Two-Eyed Seeing - Advances in Interdisciplinary Earth Science Research, Learning, and Inclusion through Shared Ways of Knowing
awd_abstract_narration:
Geoheritage and Two-Eyed Seeing (GTS) is an exploratory place-based project that combines Indigenous knowledge with geoscience education and research. A project team that crosses disciplines, generations and cultures will study dynamic and interconnected geologic and human stories about the landscape’s past, present, and future.  The project will employ equitable knowledge exchange and other ways of knowing to understand the foundations of Earth processes. GTS aligns with the pressing societal need to expand and support diversity in the geoscience community. The project engages innovative interdisciplinary perspectives and new expertise, which challenges conventional ways of thinking about the Earth. The project aims to broaden considerations of the relationships between people, landscapes, and Earth systems processes. The work is expected to contribute to the evolving field of geoheritage in the United States. Results will demonstrate how braided knowledge system approaches nurture and complement deeper understanding of diverse perspectives and increase awareness of Indigenous histories, language, and knowledge of geologic landscapes among the broader public. The diverse team will also cultivate social consciousness through shared dialogue on critical issues related to belonging, access, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion (BAJEDI) through amplifying currently underrepresented knowledge sets in the geoscience community. The project will result in the creation of a geoatlas that includes geologic, geographic and cultural data, which will be available to a range of stakeholders in the Great Lakes Region.  The project also engages tribal and non-tribal youth in digital storytelling and geoheritage research.  

In this project setting, the Keweenaw region of Michigan’s Upper Peninsula on Lake Superior, GTS explores relationships with the Earth through the lens of both Anishinaabe-gikendaasowin (Anishinaabe knowledge) and Western science with two objectives: 1) the creation of a geoatlas – a publicly accessible, exploratory geoheritage database that combines physical, cultural, and geographic datasets that will serve the scientific community, educators, local tourist entities, land use planners, and the broader public; and 2) cultivate youth leaders by fostering cultural competency in tandem with other essential skills for career paths in the geosciences. To achieve these goals an interdisciplinary team of Great Lakes Indigenous knowledge holders, geoscience/geospatial researchers, and two cohorts of tribal and non-tribal youth will braid knowledge sets documenting the way that Nibi (water), Mishomis Grandfathers (rocks), Miskwaabik (copper), and geologic processes have guided and continue to mold culture and life. These qualitative data will be integrated as innovative geoheritage data layers in the geoatlas expressing these relationships in a holistic way offering potentially transformative impacts for the development of digital storytelling and long-term geoheritage research and increased cultural competency among the broader public. Further contributions of this work include: a) cultivating a diverse geoscience community by introducing youth to geoscience career pathways through multi- disciplinary, -cultural, and –directional learning about Earth systems processes; b) creating foundations for transformative place-based, inclusive, and culturally-appropriate K-12 Earth science and higher education geoheritage curriculum, both informed by GTS project deliverables; and c) fostering a more diverse and equitable geoscience community through elevating currently underrepresented Indigenous knowledge sets in the geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
Geoheritage and Two-Eyed Seeing (GTS) considers the dynamic and interconnected geologic and human stories that serve as the foundation of our landscape's past, present, and future through equitable knowledge exchange and multiple ways of knowing about our Earth. In the project setting, the Keweenaw region of Michigan's Upper Peninsula on Lake Superior, we explored this opportunity through the lens of both Indigenous and Western values and relationships with land and water to demonstrate a regional, place-based approach for broadening participation and elevating currently underrepresented knowledge in the geosciences. Geoheritage, an evolving field in the US, emphasizes the importance of the varied personal values people have for geologic features and explores the wide-ranging relationships we have with landscapes. As such, we use a geoheritage framework as a place-based learning tool to explore the varied relationships people have had, and continue to have, with the rich geodiversity of the Keweenaw. GTS created an accessible platform for people to learn about deep time, Earth's dynamic processes, and importantly, the diverse relationships and reciprocity people have with our geologic underpinnings.

GTS has two significant outcomes: 1) the successful creation and implementation of a geoheritage and geospatial pilot program rooted in multiple ways of knowing about place - the Geoheritage Summer Internship, and 2) the creation of the Keweenaw Geoheritage Geoatlas - an accessible, exploratory geoheritage database that aggregates physiographic, cultural, and anthropological datasets. This work was facilitated as a partnership between the Keweenaw Bay Indian Community's Natural Resources Department and Tribal Historic Preservation Office, and Michigan Tech's Great Lakes Research Center and Geospatial Research Facility. 

An interdisciplinary, multi-aged, and multicultural project team developed the Geoheritage Summer Internship offering a two-week experience for local tribal and non-tribal high school students. The first week entailed a 5-day field experience that engaged students in shared ways of knowing about the landscape, culture, and heritage of our place through braided knowledge sets. Our team selected culturally significant and valued sites for the Keweenaw Bay Indian Community that also offer exceptional opportunities to learn about Earth's history. Students collected and documented their learning experience through the collection of photos, audio recordings, and drawings with a geoheritage collection app created by undergraduate interns participating in GTS from regional university and tribal colleges. The second week of the internship entailed a geospatial workshop where participants used the data collected in the field to develop StoryMaps that reflected the varied relationships people have with the landscape and how geologic processes have guided and continue to mold culture and life in our place. The internship created opportunities for a) collaborative field experiences, teamwork, and networking, b) increased Earth science and cultural literacy, c) geospatial skill development, and d) the creation, publication, and presentation of a StoryMap. The student-level data collected from this project indicates geoheritage is a pedagogical approach that can stimulate student interest in the natural sciences, foster interest in geology, and help them understand Earth Science concepts. The StoryMaps created illustrate an increased sense of gratitude and responsibility to place, greater understanding of environmental justice issues in the community rooted in Earth systems processes, and deepened sense of belonging and their own relationships with landscape.

GTS also facilitated the creation of the Keweenaw Geoheritage Geoatlas. This innovative atlas is a knowledge directed exploration geodatabase and interface that integrates physiographic landscape-wide feature coverages with other significant geospatial datasets. Year one of this project focused on the geospatial team identifying and compiling geospatial coverages - developed or acquired. In year two a user-interface was developed to access the geoatlas structure with appropriate spatial referencing and attribute-based descriptive content. This atlas is an accessible, exploratory geoheritage database that aggregates the following datasets: a) physiographic datasets, b) cartographic datasets, c) cultural datasets, and d) aerial photography datasets. Qualitative field data collected by high school interns was also integrated into the atlas as a novel geoheritage data layer, as well as a Geoheritage Reflection tab that shares the StoryMaps created during the field experience. The Keweenaw Geoheritage Geoatlas is a web resource open to be shared with the scientific community, educators, local tourist entities, land use planners, and the broader public.

Further impacts include: 1) cultivating a diverse geoscience community by inspiring shifts in learning and geoscience career trajectories among tribal and non-tribal high school and undergraduate participants of GTS, 2) increased cultural competency through multi- disciplinary, -cultural, and -directional learning about our varied relationships with Earth; 3) deepened understanding of the physical and cultural impacts of environmental justice issues within our community that are rooted in Earth systems processes, 4) laying a foundation for transformative place-based, inclusive, and culturally-appropriate K-12 Earth science and higher education geoheritage curriculum, and 5) creating opportunities for regional partnerships with other communities exploring similar opportunities for youth to engage in multiple ways of knowing about place. 


 


Last Modified: 02/28/2024
Modified by: Erika Vye
